                                                        • CFD – Advection and Diffusion

                                                        CFD之扩散和对流

                                                        General Diffusion Advection Equation

                                                        ∂c∂t+u∇c=D∇2⁡c

                                                        Numerical Differentiation Basics

                                                        Finite Differences (FD)

                                                        ui+1=ui+hui′+h22!ui″+h33!ui‴+O(h4)ui−1=ui−hui′+h22!ui″−h33!ui‴+O(h4)

                                                        Basic Differences

                                                        • Forward Difference (FD):

                                                          ui′=ui+1−uih+O(h)

                                                        • Backward Difference (BD):

                                                          ui′=ui−ui−1h+O(h)

                                                        • Central Difference (CD): (Higher accuracy)

                                                          • 1st Order: ​

                                                            ui′=ui+1−ui−12h+O(h2)

                                                          • 2nd Order (Usually CD):

                                                            ui″=ui+1−2ui+ui−1h2+O(h2)

                                                        Taylor Table

                                                        Use certain stencil points to get a certain order of Approximation

                                                        3 points -> highest accuracy: 2nd order; 4 pt -> 3rd order

                                                        -> Example: ui−2, ui−1, ui and ui+1 to approximate ui′​ of the highest order. (At most 4 equations)

                                                        a−2ui−2+a−1ui−1+a0ui+a1ui+1=a−2(ui−2Δui′+(−2Δ)22!ui′′−(−2Δ)33!ui′′′+(−2Δ)44!ui(4)+O(Δ5))+a−1(ui−Δui′+(−Δ)22!ui″−(−Δ)33!ui′′′+(−Δ)44!ui(4)+O(Δ5))+a0ui+a1(ui+Δui′+(Δ)22!ui′′+(Δ)33!ui′′′+(Δ)44!ui(4)+O(Δ5))=(a−2+a−1+a0+a1)ui+Δ(−2a−2−a−1+a1)ui′+Δ22!((−2)2a−2+(−1)2a−1+12a1)ui″+Δ33!((−2)3a−2+(−1)3a−1+13a1)ui‴+O(Δ4)

                                                        The section of ui′​ has a result of 1 and other sections equal to 0, which is

                                                        {a−2+a−1+a0+a1=0−2a−2−a−1+a1=1(−2)2a−2+(−1)2a−1+12a1=0(−2)3a−2+(−1)3a−1+13a1=0

                                                        The third order approx. result: (for lower accuracy just reduce the amount of equations)

                                                        ui′+O(Δ3)=16ui−2−ui−1+12ui+13ui+1Δ=ui−2−6ui−1+3ui+2ui+16Δ

                                                        Leading Error:

                                                        Δ34!((−2)416+(−1)4(−1)+1413)ui(4)=Δ312ui(4)

                                                        Basic Concepts

                                                        Consistency: numerical scheme vs differential equation: Truncation error

                                                        + Stability: properties of the numerical scheme with determined parameters (spatial and time steps)

                                                        = Convergence: numerical solution vs the exact solution of the differential equation

                                                        von Neumann Stability Analysis

                                                        Applying Fourier expansion for the pt. with index j @ timestep n, i is the imaginary part.

                                                        cjn=ξjneikjxj

                                                        Want: |ξ|≤1​​ (in complex domain should be ξ​ in the unit circle (Im2+Re2≤1​))

                                                        Boundary Conditions

                                                        • Dirichlet Condition: Given the values at the boundary;
                                                        • Neumann Condition: Given the derivative at the boundary.

                                                         

                                                        Diffusion

                                                        1D Steady Diffusion

                                                        (The equation itself is linear for second order derivative 0)

                                                        Discretization:

                                                        ∂2c∂x2=0⇒ci+1−2ci+ci−1Δx2=0ci=ci+1+ci−12

                                                        2D Steady Diffusion

                                                        Add y direction

                                                        ∂2c∂x2+∂2c∂y2=0⇒ci+1,j−2ci,j+ci−1,jΔx2+ci,j+1−2ci,j+ci,j−1Δy2=0

                                                        If Δx=Δy: (5 pt. scheme)

                                                        ci+1,j+ci−1,j+ci,j+1+ci,j−1−4ci,j=0

                                                        1D Unsteady Diffusion

                                                        Heat Equation / Mass Transfer Equation (PDE)

                                                        ∂c∂t=D∂2c∂x2

                                                        FTCS (Explicit) (No Source)

                                                        FTCS = Forward Time Center Space

                                                        cin+1−cinΔt=Dci+1n−2cin+ci−1nΔx2cin+1=cin+DΔtΔx2(ci+1n−2cin+ci−1n)

                                                        (Superscripts = timestep numbers; Subscripts = Spatial positions (in x-dir.))

                                                        • Introduce Evolutionary Parameter: (r>0)
                                                        r=DΔtΔx2

                                                        After organization:

                                                        cin+1=(1−2r)cin+r(ci+1n+ci−1n)

                                                        Truncation Error: O(Δt,Δx2)

                                                        • von Neumann Analysis: (Stability test)
                                                        ξn+1eik xi=(1−2r)ξneik xi+r(ξneik xi+1+ξneik xi−1)ξ=1−2r+r(eikΔx+e−ikΔx)=1+2r(cos⁡(kΔx)−1)=1−4rsin2⁡(kΔx2)

                                                        So the stable condition for r: (r​ has an upper limit)

                                                        −1≤1−4rsin2⁡(kΔx2)≤1⇒0≤r≤12

                                                        Δt should be sufficiently small compared to Δx

                                                        • Remark:

                                                          1. True domain of independence: the horizontal line t=(n+1)Δt
                                                          2. for r>1/2: cin​ has a negative weight => unstable

                                                        • Modified Equation

                                                          [∂c∂t]in−D[∂2c∂x2]in=−Δt2[∂2c∂t2]in+D12Δx2[∂4c∂x4]in+O(Δt2,Δx4)=−12DΔx2(r−16)[∂4c∂x4]in+O(Δt2,Δx4)

                                                          (LHS = Real PDE; RHS = Numerical Equation + Truncation Error)

                                                          • 0≤r<16: 4th order anti-dissipative (反耗散), need further investigation to guarantee stability
                                                          • r=16: Truncation Error: −1540DΔx4[∂6c∂x6]in+O(Δt3,Δx6)
                                                          • 16<r≤12: 4th order dissipative (the peak will be lower and lower by numerical dissipative)

                                                        FTCS (With Point Source)

                                                        The point source here is represented as Qi​ in a spatial step Δx (because although actually it’s a point, in numerical method the intensity of a point source will become infinity)

                                                        cin+1−cinΔt=Dci+1n−2cin+ci−1nΔx2+QinΔxcin+1=(1−2r)cin+r(ci+1n+ci−1n)+QinΔtΔx

                                                        BTCS (Implicit)

                                                        cjn+1−cjnΔt=DΔx2(cj+1n+1−2cjn+1+cj−1n+1)−rcj−1n+1+(1+2r)cjn+1−rcj+1n+1=cjn

                                                        Can prove unconditionally stable (e.g. von Neumann). But computation cost higher than explicit.

                                                        • Tridiagonal First Row: (Dirichlet Boundary)

                                                          (1+2r)c1n+1−rc2n+1=c1n+rc0n+1

                                                          This is going to apply using matrices operation. c0n+1 is moved to the RHS for the first row. For the second row no need to move because the LHS will start with c1n+1.

                                                          Can be proved 4th order dissipative (stable) (Leading error) by modified equation

                                                        Leapfrog

                                                        cin+1−cin−12Δt=Dci+1n−2cin+ci−1nΔx2
                                                        du Fort-Frankel

                                                        (an alternative version of Leapfrog)

                                                        cin+1−cin−12Δt=DΔx2(ci+1n−cin+1−cin−1+ci−1n)

                                                        Difference: No cin​ in the equation

                                                        Not uniformly consistent.

                                                        Crank-Nicolson

                                                        Can achieve 2nd order accuracy by 1st order equation. Use leapfrog for cin+12 (assumption, cn+12 is regarded as the average of the n and n+1) in the RHS.

                                                        cin+1−cinΔt=Dci+1n+12−2cin+12+ci−1n+12Δx2cin+1=cin+r2[(ci+1n+1−2cin+1+ci−1n+1)+(ci+1n−2cin+ci−1n)]−rci−1n+1+(2+2r)cin+1−rci+1n+1=rci−1n+(2−2r)cin+rci+1n

                                                        Tridiagonal Matrix.

                                                        Can prove unconditionally stable (e.g. von Neumann). But computation cost higher than explicit.

                                                        Another way of interpreting C-N: for cin+12​, the lower part uses FTCS (explicit) and the upper part uses BTCS (implicit).

                                                        cin+12−cinΔt2=Dci−1n−2cin+ci+1nΔx2cin+1−cin+12Δt2=Dci−1n+1−2cin+1+ci+1n+1Δx2
                                                        • Truncation Error: O(Δt2,Δx2)

                                                        θ Method (Unification)

                                                        (Weighted average explicit-implicit)

                                                        cin+1=cin+r[θ(ci+1n+1−2cin+1+ci−1n+1)+(1−θ)(ci+1n−2cin+ci−1n)]
                                                        • θ=0: FTCS
                                                        • θ=1: BTCS
                                                        • θ=12: C-N

                                                        2D Unsteady Diffusion

                                                        ∂c∂t=D(∂2c∂x2+∂2c∂y2)

                                                        FTCS (Explicit)

                                                        ci,jn+1−ci,jnΔt=D[ci+1,jn−2ci,jn+ci−1,jnΔx2+ci,j+1n−2ci,jn+ci,j−1nΔy2]
                                                        ci,jn+1=ci,jn+DΔtΔx2(ci+1,jn−2ci,jn+ci−1,jn)+DΔtΔy2(ci,j+1n−2ci,jn+ci,j−1n)

                                                         

                                                         

                                                        Advection

                                                        1D Advection

                                                        ∂c∂t+u∂c∂x=0 (suppose u>0)
                                                        • Exact solution: a wave propagating along the characteristic lines (x−ut=const​) with constant amplitude (without subsidence).
                                                        • Real influence region (for one point): points on the characteristic line.
                                                        • Inherent problem: algorithmic dissipation and dispersion in the truncation errors.

                                                        FTBS (Explicit Upwind)

                                                        FTBS = Forward Time Backward Space

                                                        cin+1−cinΔt+ucin−ci−1nΔx=0cin+1=cin−uΔtΔx(cin−ci−1n)Cr=uΔtΔxCourant number

                                                        • Courant Number: represents the ratio of the true and numerical advection velocities.

                                                          • Cr=1: In one time step travelled one space step
                                                          • Cr>1: In one time step travelled more than one space step
                                                          • Cr<1: In one time step travelled less than one space step

                                                          The iterative cin+1​ becomes: (The weighted average of the 2 cn)

                                                        cin+1=cin−Cr(cin−ci−1n)=(1−Cr)cin+Crci−1n

                                                        For stability, 0≤Cr≤1​

                                                        Truncation Error: O(Δx,Δt)

                                                        • Modified Equation Analysis

                                                          [∂c∂t]in+u[∂c∂x]in=0⇒[∂2c∂x∂t]in=−u[∂2c∂x2]in=−1u[∂2c∂t2]in
                                                          [∂c∂t]in+u[∂c∂x]in−0=−Δt2[∂2c∂t2]in−Δt26[∂3c∂t3]in−…+u(Δx2[∂2c∂x2]in−Δx26[∂3c∂x3]in+…)=(−Δt2[∂2c∂t2]in+uΔx2[∂2c∂x2]in)+(−Δt6[∂3c∂t3]in−uΔx6[∂3c∂x3]in)+…

                                                           

                                                          Connected with the numerically solution and replace with the Courant Number:

                                                          [∂c∂t]in+u[∂c∂x]in=12uΔx(1−Cr)[∂2c∂x2]in−16uΔx2(1−Cr)(1−2Cr)[∂3c∂x3]in+…

                                                          Leading Error (Section that contributes most error):

                                                          [∂c∂t]in=(12uΔx(1−Cr))[∂2c∂x2]in

                                                          Resembling diffusion (Not want)

                                                          • When error = 0, requires Cr=1; cin+1=ci−1n​ (Exact solution)
                                                          • Cr<1: Numerical diffusion (smoothing)
                                                          • Cr>1: Anti-diffusion (D<0, the peak will be very high -> ∞​)

                                                        • Truncation Error

                                                          • Second Order: (Even)

                                                            • a∂2c∂x2→Numerically diffusion
                                                            • −a∂2c∂x2→Anti-diffusion

                                                          • Third Order: (Odd) (Dispersion -> oscillation solution)

                                                            • ±a∂3c∂x3→Numerical dispersion

                                                          • Fourth Order: (Reverse 2nd order)

                                                            • −a∂4c∂x4→Numerical diffusion
                                                            • +a∂4c∂x4→Anti-diffusion

                                                        • Courant-Friedrichs-Lewy (CFL) Stability Condition (Necessary but not sufficient condition)

                                                          In order for a method to be stable, the difference domain of dependence must contain the differential one.

                                                        • von Neumann Stability Analysis

                                                          cin+1=(1−Cr)cin+Crci−1nξn+1eikxi=(1−Cr)ξneikxi+Crξneikxi−1ξ=1−Cr+Cre−ikΔx=1−Cr+Crcos⁡(kΔx)−iCrsin⁡(kΔx)
                                                          |ξ|2=(1−Cr+Crcos⁡(kΔx))2+Cr2sin2⁡(kΔx)=1+2Cr(Cr−1)(1−cos⁡(kΔx))=1+4Cr(Cr−1)sin2⁡(kΔx2)

                                                          The condition of stable: 0<Cr≤1

                                                        *FTFS (Downwind)

                                                        cin+1−cinΔt+uci+1n−cinΔx=0cin+1=cin−Cr(ci+1n−cin)=−Crci+1n+(1+Cr)cin

                                                        Depend on points that a forward, disobey physics.

                                                        Unconditionally unstable.

                                                        *FTCS (Explicit Euler)

                                                        cin+1−cinΔt+uci+1n−ci−1n2Δx=0⇒cin+1=cin−Cr2(ci+1n−ci−1n)

                                                        • von Neumann

                                                          ξn+1eikxi=ξneikxi−Cr2(ξneikxi+1−ξneikxi−1)ξ=1−Cr2(eikΔx−e−ikΔx)=1−Crcos⁡(kΔx)

                                                          Impossible to get |ξ|≤1

                                                        BTCS (Implicit Euler)

                                                        (Most of the implicit algorithms are defined as backward algorithms)

                                                        Actually solve a tri-diagonal matrix.

                                                        cin+1−cinΔt+uci+1n+1−ci−1n+12Δx=0Cr2ci+1n+1+cin+1−Cr2ci−1n+1=cin

                                                        • von Neumann

                                                          Cr2ξn+1eikxi+1+ξn+1eikxi−Cr2ξn+1eikxi−1=ξneikxi⇒Cr2ξ(eikΔx−e−ikΔx)+ξ=1ξ=1Cr isin⁡(kΔx)+1|ξ|2=11+(Crsin⁡(kΔx))2≤1

                                                          So this scheme is unconditionally stable. Δt and Δx​​ can be chosen especially to converge faster (larger Δt)

                                                        BTBS (Implicit Downwind)

                                                        cin+1=(11+Cr)cin+(Cr1+Cr)ci−1n+1

                                                        This scheme is unconditionally stable.

                                                        But BTBS assumes that boundary information travels infinitely fast into the solution domain, thus the solution resembles more that of the diffusion equation than one for advection.

                                                        Leapfrog

                                                        (2nd order acc.)

                                                        cin+1−cin−12Δt+uci+1n−ci−1n2Δx=0cin+1=cin−1−Cr(ci+1n−ci−1n)

                                                        • von Neumann

                                                          ξn+1eikxi=ξn−1eikxi−Cr(ξneikxi+1−ξneikxi−1)ξ2=1−2Crξisin⁡(kΔx)ξ2+2Crξisin⁡(kΔx)−1=0⇒ξ=−Cr isin⁡(kΔx)±1−(Crsin⁡(kΔx))2
                                                          • If 1−(Crsin⁡(kΔx))2≥0 ⇒|ξ|2=1−(Crsin⁡(kΔx))2+(Crsin⁡(kΔx))2=1
                                                          • If 1−(Crsin⁡(kΔx))2<0​ ⇒|ξ|2>1

                                                          So the condition of stable: Cr≤1​.

                                                        • Remark: Leapfrog is not self-starting i.e. need another scheme to start.

                                                         

                                                         

                                                        Advection Diffusion

                                                        1D SS Advection Diffusion

                                                        u∂c∂x=∂2c∂x2uci+1−ci−12Δx−Dci+1−2ci+ci−1Δx2=0

                                                        Grid cell Peclet Number

                                                        The ratio between advection and diffusion to compare which one is dominant. In the numerical method definition:

                                                        P=uΔxD=Crr=uΔtΔxDΔtΔx2(2−P)ci+1−4ci+(2+P)ci−1=0

                                                        Solve c (suppose c​ is of the form of polynomial)

                                                        cj=kj⇒k1=1,k2=2+P2−Pcj=a1+a2(2+P2−P)j

                                                        If P>2​​, huge oscillation occurs. So we should limit 0<P<2

                                                        (Trivious solution P=2)

                                                        Generalized Upwind

                                                        Introduce α to reduce the oscillation

                                                        dcdx=12Δx[(1−α)(cj+1−cj)+(1+α)(cj−cj−1)]u2Δx[(ci+1−ci−1)−α(ci+1−2ci+ci−1]−Dci+1−2ci+ci−1Δx2=0cj=kj⇒k1=1,k2=2+(1+α)P2−(1−α)P

                                                        We are actually solving

                                                        udcdt−(D+12αuΔx)d2cdx2=0

                                                        (Problem: D is increasing, higher diffusion, smoother => inaccuracy)

                                                        1D Unsteady Advection Diffussion

                                                        ∂c∂t+u∂c∂x=∂2c∂x2

                                                        FTBS for Advection, FTCS for Diffusion

                                                        cin+1−cinΔt+ucin−ci−1nΔx=Dci+1n−2cin+ci−1nΔx2
                                                        • Truncation Error: O(Δx,Δt)​ (1st order)

                                                        Both FTCS

                                                        cin+1−cinΔt+uci+1n−ci−1n2Δx=Dci+1n−2cin+ci−1nΔx2cin+1=cin+r(ci+1n−2cin+ci−1n)−Cr2(ci+1n−ci−1n)

                                                        • von Neumann

                                                          ξ=1+r(eikΔx−2+e−ikΔx)−Cr2(eikΔx−e−ikΔx)=1+2r(cos⁡(kΔx)−1)−iCrsin⁡(kΔx)=1−4rsin2⁡(kΔx2)−iCrsin⁡(kΔx)|ξ|2=(1−4rsin2⁡(kΔx2))2+Cr2sin2⁡(kΔx)

                                                          • If kΔx=π:

                                                            (1−4r)2≤1⇒0≤r≤12

                                                          • If kΔx→0: (neglect the 4th order terms)

                                                            (1−4r(kΔx2)2)2+Cr2(kΔx)2=1−2r(kΔx)2+Cr2(kΔx)2=1+(Cr2−2r)(kΔx)2≤1⇒Cr2≤2r

                                                          To recap: Cr2≤2r≤1

                                                        Crank-Nicolson

                                                        cin+1−cinΔt+12u(ci+1n+1−ci−1n+12Δx+ci+1n−ci−1n2Δx)=12D(ci+1n+1−2cin+1+ci−1n+1Δx2−ci+1n−2cin+ci−1nΔx2)−(r+Cr2)ci−1n+1+(2+2r)cin+1−(r−Cr2)ci+1n+1=(r+Cr2)ci−1n+(2−2r)cin+(r−Cr2)ci+1n

                                                        • von Neumann

                                                          −(r+Cr2)ξe−ikΔx+(2+2r)ξ−(r−Cr2)ξeikΔx=(r+Cr2)e−ikΔx+2−2r+(r−Cr2)eikΔx
                                                          ξ(−2rcos⁡(kΔx)+2isin⁡(kΔx)+2+2r)=2rcos⁡(kΔx)−2isin⁡(kΔx)+2−2r
                                                          ξ=r(cos⁡(kΔx)−1)−isin⁡(kΔx)+1−r(cos⁡(kΔx)−1)+isin⁡(kΔx)+1=1−2rsin2⁡(kΔx2)−isin⁡(kΔx)1+2rsin2⁡(kΔx2)+isin⁡(kΔx)<1

                                                          Unconditionally stable.

                                                        2D Unsteady Advection Diffusion

                                                        Containing point source / sink (δ means only at a point there is Q) and even reactions (in this equation 1st order kinects)

                                                        ∂c∂t+u∂c∂x+v∂c∂y=D(∂2c∂x2+∂2c∂y2)+δ(source/sink)Q−kc(reaction/decay)
